page.title: 01BALMACARA SQUARE
page.content: The inaccesible land to the N>E> of Balmacara Square rises as high as 425m, contains many steep slopes, hill summits and bare rock outcrops, and is extremely hilly in nature. This land is covered by shallow peaty soil which can support only poor grassland, heather or forestry. The dominant cover is varied coniferous forest, planted for amenity by the National Trust, who are the main landowners. There is also a rare area of natural oak woodland. Before the Trust arrived in 1946, roe deer were s eldom seen. Today they are frequently spotted, as are pine-martens who are now so common, they forage in the square itself. Balmacara Square sits lower down in an area of flatter, better quality land and has a population of 84 save 1 farmer and visits from foresters.
